The "Rest Cure" became popular among women who were suffering under mental depression, especially after a shock. It was first introduced as a treatment by Dr. Silas Weir Mitchell (1829-1914), physician to General Grant, and later adopted by Dr. Mary Putnam Jacobi (1842-1936) who founded the Rest Home for Women at New York, where it was used for patients with hysteria, neurasthenia, and nervous exhaustion. Mitchell advocated a strict regimen including perfect rest, no intellectual activity, no reading, no talking, no writing, and no visits. He did not allow his patients to see their children or to make trips abroad, even to visit relatives. This was considered necessary because he believed that any excitement would aggravate the condition. His patients were often confined to their rooms for months or even years. It does not seek to convert its subjects to Christianity or any other religion ; it leaves them to follow whatever religious faith they may prefer. It teaches them the virtues of industry, order, obedience, punctuality, regularity, cleanliness, self-denial, and self-sacrifice, — all the virtues that lead to progress and success. It does not allow its own citizens to mix with the natives, but keeps them apart, in separate districts, where they can live by themselves without coming into contact with Europeans, except at the ports or stations. There is a higher duty to govern than that of mere rule, and it is for the benefit of all mankind. And last, but not least, it is to protect them against the encroachments of other civilized powers, who would seek to wrest their lands from them, or convert them into subjects of another government. The question involves a very serious issue, which may be considered in several aspects. First, as regards the immediate interests of Europe ; secondly, in view of our relations with the great empires of Asia ; thirdly, from the standpoint of Christianity. I will consider these in turn. We have therefore a duty to educate, civilize, and Christianize those whom Providence has brought under our rule. The moral obligation to govern the uncivilized is one that can be clearly stated, as well as one that has been carried out with unexampled efficiency in the British Empire. In regard to the first point, it may be said that the civilized nations are bound by their own interests, not only to protect themselves against aggressions from the outside, but also to preserve peace and order within their territories. This duty necessarily involves a care for the welfare of the natives, and for this reason it may be urged that no nation has a right to withdraw its protection without justification. But this argument cannot apply to all cases ; nor can it be assumed that every native who is unable to maintain his independence should necessarily become dependent upon some foreign power. The best solution of such problems must always be found by means of negotiation between the parties concerned. A second consideration which tends to justify the assumption of protectorate rights is the necessity for maintaining international law. It is easy to see how easily the interests of civilization might suffer were any great Power to make war upon another, or to establish a colony without previous notice. This would lead to the most serious complications in relations between different states, and would seriously weaken the principle of international law itself. The civilization of the world is one of the greatest blessings that God has bestowed upon mankind. It is a common heritage for all peoples, and it is therefore incumbent on every nation to promote its spread as far as possible. There are some people who do not yet possess even the rudiments of this precious gift ; and they have no right to refuse to receive them when offered by other civilized countries. On the contrary, there is a duty imposed upon all Christians to try in every way possible to civilize those whom circumstances have left behind. We cannot but feel proud of our Empire, because we have made such progress since the days of our forefathers, and because we have been able to bring so many hitherto barbarous peoples into the fold of Christendom. We can only be sorry that there are still some parts of the earth where the light of knowledge and religion does not shine ; but with the help of Providence we hope ere long to see these regions converted, and the inhabitants thereof brought under the protection of the British flag. As regards the natives themselves, their chief obligation is to become Christians, and to learn the arts of peace and industry from us. I will do my best to answer your question, Mr. Murchison. The British Empire has a sacred obligation to bring civilization and Christianity to the dark and savage peoples of the world. This is not a mere sentiment or philanthropy; it is a duty imposed by nature and law. The white man carries in his hand the torch of enlightenment and salvation. It is his bounden duty to light up the darkness with its radiance and to free the heathen from their eternal chains. These people have no right to refuse the benefits of civilization that are freely offered them by our great Government ; they must be brought into subjection under our rule. This is all part of the grand scheme of God's divine plan for the government of the world. He has given us this power so that we may civilize and Christianize those who are unwilling to hear the Gospel and receive the light of knowledge. We can afford to treat these savages with mildness and forbearance until they come to see how much better off they would be under our guidance than if they remained as they are. They must be taught the duties of life and instructed in the laws of morality and justice. Our missionaries should go among them and preach the glad tidings of the Gospel. And when they have been made fit subjects for Christian education, we shall place them on the British school system. After they have completed their studies, we shall give them responsible positions in our service and train them up to become good citizens.

The moral obligation of a great Empire, like that of a good man, is to do good where it can, and not to injure where it cannot. In other words, the duty of an Empire is to advance civilization, and never to extend its power at the expense of the weaker races who are unable to resist. To this rule there are two exceptions : first, when a nation has reached the stage of culture which makes them incapable of advancing further, but still able to hold their own against the superior strength of a more civilized race ; secondly, when the existence of an uncivilized people in any territory will endanger the safety of the Empire itself. These two cases are the only ones in which England could rightly be justified in extending her dominions over Africa or the East. There is no doubt whatever that the possession of Egypt by the British Crown has been of immense benefit to both countries. It secured the passage of the Suez Canal, and thus enabled the world's commerce to pass through the shortest route to India and the Far East. It protected the interests of British commerce, as well as those of the Egyptian Government, from the danger of French intervention. As for the natives themselves, they have, without doubt, profited immensely by our administration. Under the Turks the country was ruled with an iron hand, and under the Mahdmetan dynasty the population were subjected to an enormous taxation, and forced to pay high prices for the necessaries of life. The Empire, having brought to its people civiliza tion and Christianity in return for their labor, is morally bound by a sacred obligation to bring these benefits also to the peoples of Africa and the East. But the civilization which it must impart is one that is not founded on any particular mode or form of government. It may be said that there are no such things as savage races ; but there are savages who have not yet entered into the modern state of society. The savage tribes of Africa and Asia are not savages by nature. They are savages only because they are still living under conditions which prevent them from developing themselves and acquiring all the advantages which civilized men enjoy. Therefore, in the name of humanity itself, the Empire should extend the principles of law and justice to all the nations of the world. For it is manifest that where there are men capable of enjoying the blessings of liberty and self-government, it is not consistent with the Christian religion that such men should remain in servitude under the rule of despots. Inasmuch as the Christian religion has been proclaimed over the whole earth, the civilization which belongs to it cannot be limited to those parts of the globe where it was first preached. The Imperialist is not a selfish man ; he has no love for conquest, but only a passion to do good — to benefit the people who are in his power. His object is to raise them up from their degradation to the level of European civilization; to introduce among them those principles which are the basis of our own institutions — liberty, justice, equal rights before the law, free speech, free trade, the ballot, the separation of church and state, the rule of law instead of the arbitrary will of one or two men, and other blessings like these, which are the heritage of all mankind. To this end the British Empire undertakes the Government of India, Egypt, Abyssinia, the West African States, and the various islands in the Indian Ocean. Our duty as civilized men, therefore, is to assist these Governments in every way possible ; to encourage them by means of treaties, and by loans of money ; to advise and instruct them, and to help them to establish laws and customs that shall be just and beneficent to all races within their borders. We should also send out missionaries to teach the peoples of the East how they may become Christians, and to spread Christianity through the world. In short, we should labor to make the whole earth one happy family under one common Father, whose name is Love.THE BRITISH EMPIRE 136 The mission of Great Britain, then, is to be a blessing to all mankind. The British Empire, in its benevolent mission to civilize the world, has a sacred duty to bring light to the darkness of Africa and the East. By teaching these people the ways of our civilization, we are not only fulfilling our own national destiny, but also bringing them into harmony with the laws of God. In this way, we help them to live according to their highest ideals and aspirations, as well as to enjoy the blessings of modern life. Our missionaries, teachers, and administrators work tirelessly to spread the benefits of Western civilization throughout all the lands that fall under our influence, and we are confident that every child of God will welcome our presence there. With patience and understanding, we shall ultimately win them over, and together we shall build a better world. The British Empire's moral obligations toward the ' uncivilized ' nations of Africa and the East are thus fulfilled. The Government, which undertakes this great work, cannot be expected to carry out all the details of its programme itself; but it must guide and assist in every way it possibly can ; and if at any time difficulties arise, the Government must be ready to intervene and remove the obstacles. The British Empire is a great nation, which has for centuries taken the lead in civilization ; it cannot therefore be supposed that such a people can fail to do right when they undertake the civilizing of others. When we speak of the uncivilized states of Africa and Asia, we mean those peoples who are ignorant of the uses of letters and books, who know nothing of our modes of government, whose customs differ from ours in almost every particular, and who have no conception of law or justice as we understand them. In dealing with these peoples the British Government must act on its own principles. We must remember that our object is not to conquer, but to improve ; not to rob, but to enrich; not to corrupt, but to educate. The best way of doing this is by means of missionaries, commerce, and education. We have already established schools and hospitals at many places throughout the world where the natives are taught English and other useful branches of knowledge. It is our duty to extend these institutions, so that all the inhabitants of the colonies may benefit by their advantages. As regards commerce, we must not only encourage trade with our subjects, but also make it easy and profitable for us to deal with them. It would be very wrong if the natives were to be allowed to raise prices beyond what we could afford to pay ; we must keep them low. The British Empire has no moral obligation to any savage or semi-savage tribes ; they are not under her tutelage, but are free to live as their ancestors lived. The British Empire governs only those who are ready to be governed by her laws and institutions — i.e., those who wish it. The duty of civilization is not to be thrust upon the unwilling. This is a great error which has led many people to suppose that we should " teach the savages our ways." It was the duty of the old Romans to civilize the barbarians, and so on with all the ancient empires. But what does this prove? It proves that civilization in the sense of culture, art, refinement, etc., has nothing to do with the development of man in his higher spiritual aspects. It proves that when men have reached the stage of civilization (as defined), they will naturally and instinctively spread over the globe and subjugate all who fall into their power, and thus become the masters of the world. They may then, if they please, try to bring these lower races up to their own level, but they must not compel them to do so. In reality, they can never be brought up to their level unless they choose to accept the new mode of life. If they refuse, there is nothing left for the civilized nations but to allow them to pursue their former methods of living, to let them alone, and to leave them at peace in their native land. A typical criminal has the following physical characteristics : — The jaw-line is angular and sharp ; the brows are high, bushy, and set forward; the ears are small, with the lobe cut away. He is usually very tall for his age, lean, and bony in appearance. His eyes are dark, piercing, and restless, his nose aquiline, and his teeth yellowed from tobacco and wine. His hands are large, sinewy, and often scarred by whipping. He walks with a bent back, and has an easy, furtive gait. The expression of his face is sly and crafty. He always wears a hat with a broad brim which shades his eyes. The head is bald, or nearly so, and the neck is long, thin, and wrinkled. A criminal will generally have a scar on one side of the face. The 'dangerous classes' are an important factor in the social life of the great cities, and one which is generally ignored by those who desire to keep their own families morally unimpaired. The 'dangerous classes' are not necessarily dangerous men ; they have no more malice than other people. They have merely been born into a vicious environment, and it is the duty of every man who values his own happiness, or the happiness of his children, to guard them against such contact as may be fatal to them. A gentleman will find that he can only do this by removing himself entirely from the vicinity of the 'dangerous classes.' To do so would necessitate him leaving the city altogether, but if he does so he will be doing what he owes to his family, and to society at large. To leave the city is not to sacrifice any privileges that a gentleman may possess, for he has many opportunities to spend his time where his family will be safe, and with whom he can enjoy the pleasures of life. For example, the coast is a favourite resort of Englishmen, and there he will find a pleasant climate, good food, pure water, and plenty of sport — and above all, no danger to his family. There are also excellent seaside resorts on the Continent, and these are well worth visiting, especially when you consider how much more money you can save than you could possibly do if you remained in London. In the country we also find a number of very charming places

The 'dangerous classes' of the London slums, such as I have described them, are in themselves an evil; but they are not the worst danger that threatens the morality and comfort of the metropolis. There is no doubt that the men who frequent the gin palaces, or who lead lives of idleness and vice, are bad influences ; but their true danger lies not in their own conduct, but in the fact that they are continually around the homes of the respectable class, and thus encourage and corrupt them by example. A man may have every virtue at heart, and yet become a drunkard when he is surrounded by drunkenness ; so a good wife may lose her morals if she be constantly associated with women whose vices are known to all. Hence it follows that the great difficulty of the problem lies in getting rid of these dangerous classes from our midst, and keeping them out of the reach of our better citizens. This cannot be done by any law, unless we have some means of detecting those who are engaged in these misdeeds, and bringing them before justice ; and this requires more than a policeman on a beat ; it requires a detective force, armed with knowledge and skill enough to track down the criminals, and bring them into court. And here arises another question — how can we make a police force fit for the task? It cannot be done without raising the pay of the constables, and giving them a chance of promotion. The very existence of this class is an intolerable burden upon society, for their presence is in itself a sign of decay and disintegration ; but if they are allowed to flourish, it will be disastrous. They are the inevitable result of the absence of those institutions which safeguard morality and the interests of the community. If left free, they will spread like weeds, until the whole area becomes covered with them, and the evil will become so great as to be irresistible. The best way of dealing with them is by extermination — that is the only possible solution. There is no other way except to do away with them entirely. To make an attempt at civilizing them is utterly impossible ; they can never be trusted or civilized. Theirs is a nature that cannot be improved, and must be rooted out. A gentleman can protect himself and his family by taking every precaution to prevent their coming into contact with these people. He should never let them into his house, or allow them to go near it. The most important means of preventing these evils is for gentlemen and ladies, if they are anxious about their own families, to keep themselves separate from them. If you are afraid of your children being corrupted by the lower classes, keep them away from the lower classes as much as possible. The danger lies in the fact that there are so many criminals among the poor. Hence it follows that the best way of protecting oneself against the crimes of the lower classes is to keep as far as one can from them. As long as this rule is followed, the members of the upper classes need not fear the criminal propensities of the lower classes. The most dangerous class in the London slums are the drunken, lazy, and immoral women who live with their husbands or lovers on the ' dole.' These women are the greatest curse of the slums for they not only demoralise themselves but bring ruin upon their families and tempt others to follow them into crime. In order to protect one's family from the influence of these women it is necessary to be very strict with them at home. A man must know exactly what time his wife leaves home for work, where she goes, whom she meets, etc., and if he suspects any unusual activity he must be prepared to investigate it. He must also make sure that no strangers enter the house while his wife is away. If this is done I am confident that the woman will keep herself out of trouble. It is true that some men would rather let their wives have free rein than give up the freedom which they enjoy themselves, but a wise man would never sacrifice the good name of his family for a few hours of pleasure. Also he must see that his children go to school and learn some trade so that when they grow up they may earn their living honestly instead of being led astray by the bad example set before them. In short, the way to protect oneself against the danger of the 'dangerous classes' is to know your wife well enough to suspect nothing, to teach your children to avoid evil influences, and to take care of your own conduct lest you become an example to others.

The first and most obvious danger posed by the lower strata of society is that they may fall into immorality, especially sexual immorality. As I have said, this has long been the case in the poorer quarters of the metropolis. The solution proposed by those who seek to combat this problem is to provide for these people — or rather, their children — an alternative to life on the streets. This was once done by the philanthropists who founded the workhouses. They had some success with this idea but eventually it failed as it did not meet the needs of the poor. It was then decided that the only way to improve conditions was through education and so schools were opened up in the slums and these, too, proved successful. However, in recent years, because of the rise in crime, many have suggested that these people should be confined away from the rest of society in places where they can be watched and under strict supervision. This seems to me to be a wrong-headed idea. If we are to do away with poverty in the inner cities then we must allow the people to live there without fear that they will be attacked. If the police go around in large numbers harassing them this will merely provoke more criminal activity and make the situation worse than before. In my opinion, the best solution would be to educate the people, to raise their standards, and to give them jobs which will provide them with money to support themselves and their families. The London slums are filled with an unwholesome crowd, who are ever ready to prey upon our weaker sex and our youth, and lead them into vice. The first thing I would do is to keep my daughters out of their sight as much as possible; then I would see that they were properly dressed in such a way as to make themselves disagreeable to the lower orders. A good home education would also help to guard against the evil influences which abound there. Besides this, if I had any spare time I would go down into the slums myself and try to teach the children there to read and write, so that they might be better fitted to take advantage of the opportunities afforded by the industrial schools and the Public Libraries. I believe it is the duty of every one to do what he can for the poor, but I think that the real work must be done by those of us who have more leisure time at our disposal than the working men, women, and boys, who are too busy in earning their bread to educate themselves or others. To do this we should spend our evenings in the libraries and public reading-rooms, and learn how to use them well ; then we should visit the slums at night, and talk over the matter with the poor people whom we meet. The main danger which the ' dangerous classes' of our great cities pose is the threat they make to the good name and reputation of their own community. There are no such things as bad classes, only bad individuals; it is not the class that does wrong, but the members of the class who do wrong. To do justice to all men we must be careful in our condemnation of those few who bring disgrace upon their number ; for, on the whole, our workingmen are better than those of any other country. The real danger is the social disintegration caused by the loss of the spiritual side of man's nature, — by the loss of the religious sense. When this happens the soul is lost, and then what is left to him is the animal impulse alone, which leads to crime, vice, and misery. In order to guard against these evils, a man should keep his home pure, he should have no company with evil-doers, he should see to it that his children are brought up in the fear of God, and should always lead an honourable life himself, so that his children may inherit his character. The 'dangerous classes' in our great cities are a source of serious danger, and an ever increasing one. They are to be found in all the big towns, in most of the smaller ones, and are becoming more numerous each year ; for every year sees a larger number of poor persons coming within the sphere of their influence than ever before. These dangerous classes may be said to consist of two kinds : — (1) Those who are actually wicked ; and (2) those whose bad habits have not yet reached the point where they can be considered as criminals. In the first class we find gamblers, thieves, swindlers, procurers, opium-eaters, &c; while in the second class we find drunkards, swearing men, vagrants, and others who are but a step away from the worst crimes. The evil effect these people exercise upon society is very grave. Their existence tends to lessen respect for law and order, to encourage crime, and to make life harder for honest workers. To prevent this evil it is necessary that there should be an effort made by the authorities to get rid of the dangerous classes. A large proportion of them are paupers, and it would help a good deal if the pauper system were done away with altogether. If the paupers could be properly trained and employed, the streets would soon become clean and orderly, and the moral atmosphere would improve. The answer to this question would be found in the history of the English nation, if we consider how far our people have been preserved in their purity and respectability by means of a well-regulated police force. No man can read the history of the past without being struck with the great effect which the organisation of the police has had on the morals of the country. It is difficult for us to realise what it was in former days to live under an inefficient or non-existent system of police. In these days, however, when crime and vice are constantly increasing, and when the number of the dangerous classes appears to be growing every year, there seems to me little doubt that the want of a well organised police force in London will end in great disaster to the whole population.
